newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish ruling coalition rows as minister sacked.
newsitem.headline: Polish ruling coalition rows as minister sacked.

text.p: Poland's president sacked foreign trade minister Jacek Buchacz on Wednesday, prompting a sudden crisis in the tense relations between the two parties in the ruling leftist coalition.

A government statement said Buchacz, 48, was fired on a motion by Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz after official probes revealed an improper blurring of public and private interests in the granting of export guarantees.
"The motion of the head of cabinet in this matter is linked with a need to guarantee better care over the interests of the state treasury," the government statement said.

Heads of Buchacz's Polish Peasant Party (PSL) and the larger ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) of Cimoszewicz held a crisis meeting in Warsaw but the Peasants broke off the talks in anger at not being informed of the dismissal in advance.
"The (SLD's) manner of dismissing Minister Buchacz, without informing its coalition partner, we view as an example of our partner's arrogant attitude," the PSL said in a statement.
PSL leader Waldemar Pawlak told PAP news agency the party's chiefs would meet on Friday to decide whether to resume talks with the SLD.
Buchacz himself, at a hastily convened news conference, said: "I regard my dismissal...as a clear breaking of the coalition agreement."
PSL deputy Stanislaw Bartoszek went further by suggesting the sacking was an SLD move to break up the coalition and cause early parliamentary polls, otherwise not due until September 1997.
"This was a confrontational move, designed to put the blame on the PSL for the dissolution of the coalition and early elections," Bartoszek told Reuters.
The government statement said the sacking of Buchacz was closely related to inspections by the official Supreme Auditing Chamber (NIK) and the Cabinet Supervision Office.
It said the probes concerned "the involvement of the treasury in ventures concerning export guarantees, in which state and private property is connected in a way that lacks sufficient clarity."
Buchacz did not directly answer these allegations.

But the PSL statement said his dismissal was the SLD's response to his warnings that Poland's official foreign trade deficit was likely to balloon to $10 billion by the end of 1996 from $1.8 billion last year.

The PSL and SLD have most recently clashed over the distribution of cabinet posts during a reorganisation of central government due this year, but had appeared to settle their differences with a so-far undisclosed compromise.
The coalition has linked the two parties rooted in the pre-1989 communist era, through two cabinet reshuffles, since they defeated parties stemming from Solidarity in 1993 polls.
Buchacz has been foreign trade minister since early 1995. He was appointed by the previous Prime Minister Jozef Oleksy and inherited the portfolio in the current cabinet.
Several weeks ago the government rejected plans by Buchacz to set up a new export guarantee system. His dismissal was formally signed by President Aleksander Kwasniewski.
